ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Fitness Landscape Modulation
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello Colin- I think this is a good idea, and would be interested to see if you publish (even informally) and experiments showing how well this works. I think

Subject: Re: [neat] Fitness Landscape Modulation
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=211599040; y=KF7yI33XOVs7uB3kngubATe0pTkyrpQhwNM0Vssaj04ZtQGWNtmk

Hello Colin-

I think this is a good idea, and would be interested to see if you publish
(even informally) and experiments showing how well this works.

I think you could do the same thing with mutation rates: if the population
stagnates for a while, start increasing the mutation rate until you generate
individuals in new areas of the landscape, then let the mutation rate lower
so they can exploit these new peaks, and repeat. All the while I think you'd
want to have some elitism, so you don't mutationally eradicate the best of
what you've learned so far.

Another cool idea for generating ongoing diversity, and getting the
population unstuck, is Greg Hornby's ALPS method, which has some really
promising results. I think it would be pretty interesting to see someone
combine ALPS with NEAT to see if ALPS works better than NEAT's diversity
preservation method, or whether the two together work better than either
alone, etc. 

http://idesign.ucsc.edu/projects/alps.html


Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
jclune@...
www.msu.edu/~jclune




> From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Sat, 13 Mar 2010 15:01:46 +0000
> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: [neat] Fitness Landscape Modulation
> 
> This is an idea I've been thinking about for a while. Consider a
> fitness landscape with local maxima that we tend to get stuck in. NEAT
> gives us some ways of getting out of the local high points:
> 
> 1) Speciation. Maintains multiple search 'areas' on teh landscape and
> balances search effort between them. However, speciation by itself
> doesn't provide a means of discovering new promising areas on the
> landscape.
> 2) Random mutations. Allow us to 'hop' to new but relatively proximate
> points on the landscape, e.g. single new connections/nodes and random
> resetting of connections weights.
> 3) Crossover. Attempts to find new areas, but that are close to both
> parents (typically by searching in some higher dimensional space than
> either of the parents). Hence crossover provides access to a lot of
> new search space by bringing it nearer to our current search
> points(genomes) in terms of 'edit distance'.
> 
> 
> I'm proposing that another way of opening up the fitness landscape is
> to modify that landscape such that the arrangement of landscape
> barriers changes and opens up pathways to new areas, but in a way that
> still leads to promising areas. E.g. One technique I have experimented
> with is to factor the size of a genome into the fitness function,
> motivation for this comes from mathematical regularization - simply
> that simpler models/genomes are more generalised and thus fitter than
> more complex models (depending on the problem domain).
> 
> If I enforce selection pressure against complexity I see the search
> becoming overly constrained, but if I lessen that pressure or remove
> it, allow search to continue for a while and then re-impose the
> pressure then I've found that this to be successful. You can imagine
> that I've removed a barrier in the landscape, some of the genome shave
> migrated to new areas and then I've put back the barriers and the
> genome snow settle into new local maxima and continue searching from
> there.
> 
> This idea overlaps with phased search (alternating between
> complexifying and simplifying) and could be framed as an extension of
> that approach, essentially adding more phases or more axes to the
> complex-simple axis. I also think rather than switching certain types
> of fitness criteria on/off that a smoother transition would be a more
> general solution. You can imagine the landscape as undulating and the
> genomes as ball bearings rolling around as the landscpae changes
> (except ball bearings would follow valleys instead of peaks/ridges).
> 
> Colin
> 
> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regularization_%28mathematics%29
